Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 50041-001  
Regional Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
August 2016 
 
 
 
Enhancing Coordination of the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation Program 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This  document  is  being  disclosed  to  the  public  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Public 
Communications Policy 2011. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation  
  IT  –  information technology 
NFP  –  national focal point 
OIF  –  overall institutional framework 
RCC  –  regional cooperation coordinator 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  W. Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  S. O’Sullivan, Central and West Asia Department 
Director  P. Srivastava, Officer-in-Charge, Regional Cooperation and Operations 
Coordination Division (CWRC) 
   
Team leader  G. Wu, Regional Cooperation Specialist, CWRC 
Team members  W. Hong, Principal Regional Cooperation Specialist, CWRC  
K. Rosbach, Economist (Regional Cooperation), CWRC  
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 25012016103216626437 Generated Date: 05-Aug-2016 14:09:45 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since its initiation in 2001, the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
program  has  made  significant  progress  toward  its  goal  of  development  by  promoting  and 
facilitating regional  cooperation  in  transport,  energy,  trade,  and  other key  areas  of mutual 
interest.  The  program  has  grown  to  become  a  premier  regional  cooperation  mechanism 
anchored  on  partnership  among  10  member  countries  with  the  support  of  six  multilateral 
institutions.1 The flexibility and pragmatism that guide CAREC operations have worked well in 
allowing  countries  to  proceed  multitrack  and  multispeed.  The  program  proactively  enables 
results-based regional projects and policy initiatives critical to trade expansion and sustainable 
development. CAREC operations have grown rapidly over the past 15 years. In 2001, the first 
six CAREC-related projects were approved with a combined value of $247 million. As of the end 
of 2015, a total of 166 projects have been approved with an aggregate amount of $27.7 billion, 
reinforced with policy dialogues to ensure the investment returns. Continuous support to the 
CAREC program was reiterated in the Joint Ministerial Statement of the 14th CAREC Ministerial 
Conference held in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia on 25 September 2015.2 The Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) plays a multifaceted role, including that of lead or coordinating development partner 
and  honest  broker,  provider  and  facilitator  of  investment financing,  and  secretariat for  the 
CAREC program.  
 
2.  ADB  has  supported  regional  economic  cooperation  in  Central  Asia  and  the 
implementation  of  CAREC  through  several  technical  assistance  (TA).3 Since  the  ongoing 
“umbrella”  TA  was  approved  in  August  2012,  the  program  has  entered  a  new  stage  of 
implementation and made remarkable achievements, including the following:4 
(i)  The Wuhan Action Plan, endorsed at the 11th CAREC Ministerial Meeting in 
October 2012, charts the next steps of the CAREC program, with the aim of 
achieving seamless connectivity and greater prosperity in the region. As a first 
step, the CAREC governments formulated a list of medium-term priority projects 
to mainstream regional cooperation fully into the national development strategies. 
(ii)  With regard to transport, a midterm review of the Transport and Trade Facilitation 
Strategy  was  conducted  in  2012–2013  and  a  refined  Strategy  20205 was 
endorsed at the 12th CAREC Ministerial Meeting in November 2013. To expand 
the multimodal corridor network further, priority infrastructure projects and a set 
                                                
1 The CAREC member countries are Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, the People’s Republic of China, Kazakhstan, the 
Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. The six CAREC multilateral 
institution partners are ADB, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Monetary 
Fund, the Islamic Development Bank, the United Nations Development Programme, and the World Bank. ADB is 
CAREC Secretariat. 
2  Joint Ministerial Statement at the 14th Ministerial Conference given in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia on September 2015. 
http://www.carecprogram.org/uploads/events/2015/029-14th-CAREC-Ministerial-Conference/Key-Documents/2015-
CAREC-MC-Joint-Ministerial-Statement.pdf. 
3  Earlier ADB TA projects comprise: (i) ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Enhancing Coordination of the Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program. Manila (TA 8148-REG). (ii) ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for 
Strengthening Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, 2007–2012. Manila (TA 6409-REG). (iii) ADB. 2005. 
Technical Assistance for Greater Silk Road Initiative 2006. Manila (TA 6272-REG). (iv) ADB. 2004. Technical 
Assistance for Greater Silk Road Initiative 2005. Manila (TA 6199-REG). (v) ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for 
Greater Silk Road Initiative. Manila (TA 6053-REG). (vi) ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for Regional Economic 
Cooperation in Central Asia, Phase II-Year Three. Manila (TA 5988-REG).  
4  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Enhancing Coordination of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
Program. Manila (TA 8148-REG, $3 million, approved on 30 August). The TA was implemented from September 
2012 to August 2015. After a major change of scope was approved in June 2014, the TA completion date was 
extended to 31 August 2016 and the amount increased by $2.5 million. 
5  ADB. 2014. CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy 2020. Manila.

2   
of complementary soft sector initiatives have been identified in the areas of road 
safety, railway development strategy, road asset management, and transport 
facilitation. 
(iii)  To facilitate trade, the CAREC countries have intensified efforts to (a) align their 
customs legal framework with the Revised Kyoto Convention, (b) assess the 
scope and cost of modernizing sanitary and phytosanitary measures to facilitate 
trade, and (c) establish a low-cost regional transit regime. 
(iv)  With regard to energy, progress was made under the Energy Work Plan, 2013–
2015,6 and a new Energy Strategy and Work Plan, 2016–20207 was developed 
and adopted at the 14th CAREC Ministerial Meeting in September 2015. The 
new  strategy  refines  its  focuses  on  investments  in  cross-border  energy 
infrastructure, energy trade, the development and prioritization of sustainable 
energy resources, energy efficiency, clean energy, and new technologies. 
(v)  With regard to trade policy, a Trade Policy Strategic Action Plan, 2013–2017 was 
endorsed at the 12th CAREC Ministerial Meeting in November 2013 expanding 
its  agenda  to  support the  implementation  of the World Trade Organization’s 
accession  and  post-accession  commitments;  trade  in  industrial  goods  and 
services; and tariff issues and non-tariff barriers. Two more CAREC members 
acceded  to  the  World  Trade  Organization:  Tajikistan  in  May  2013  and 
Kazakhstan in November 2015. 
(vi)  With  regard  to  economic  corridor  development,  the  Almaty–Bishkek  Corridor 
Initiative  was  endorsed  at  the  13th  Ministerial  Meeting  in  2014,  and  a  joint 
working group between the two cities was established thereafter. This initiative is 
making good progress towards completing a comprehensive report reflecting a 
holistic  and  multisectoral  approach  to  economic  corridor  development  and 
identifying the policy, institutional, and infrastructure requirements for the pilot 
initiative. 
(vii)  With regard to knowledge initiatives, the physical base of the CAREC Institute 
was launched and began initial operations in March 2015 in Urumqi, Xinjiang 
Uygur Autonomous Region, People’s Republic of China. 
3.  This policy and advisory TA8 will enable ADB to support the CAREC program further in 
its  second  decade  of  implementation,  with  the  goal  of  strengthening  regional  economic 
cooperation in the CAREC region. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  As the reintegration of the Eurasian continent gathers momentum, the CAREC countries 
have an unprecedented opportunity to emerge as a center for trade and commerce and achieve 
higher levels of inclusive economic growth. In isolation, none of the region's economies will be 
able to capture this opportunity fully, but all will benefit from working together to build on their 
strengths  for  mutual  progress.  The  CAREC  countries  are  increasingly  recognizing  the 
importance of CAREC in helping them adapt to emerging challenges in an economic landscape 
that is rapidly changing, both regionally and globally. By reflecting on key lessons from the past 
15 years and taking into account ADB’s first Regional Cooperation and Integration Operational 
Plan9 and  the  recommendations  from  the  Independent  Evaluation  Department’s  Thematic 
                                                
6  ADB. 2012. Energy Sector Coordinating Committee Work Plan 2013–2015. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2015. Strategy and Work Plan (2016–2020) for Regional Cooperation in the Energy Sector of CAREC 
Countries. Manila. 
8  The Vice-President for Operations 1 approved The TA concept paper on 13 June 2016. 
9  Under preparation and expected to be approved in the third quarter of 2016.

3 
Evaluation Study on ADB support for regional cooperation and integration,10 CAREC can further 
enhance its coordination in the following areas: 
(i)  Stronger country ownership. As CAREC countries continue to develop awareness 
of the importance of regional cooperation in achieving national development goals, 
country ownership of the CAREC program must be enhanced further to reflect the 
complementary role of regional initiatives more explicitly in their respective national 
development plans. 
(ii)  A more innovative agenda. The multiplicity of regional forums and institutions could 
strain country-level capabilities in managing their participation in various regional 
initiatives,  which  may  result  in  less  than  effective  participation  in  the  overall 
institutional CAREC framework (see Appendix 2).11 It is thus essential to innovate 
and keep agendas highly relevant to ensure the strong, consistent engagement of 
the CAREC members. 
(iii)  More responsive working mechanism. CAREC continues to undergo a widening 
and deepening process in response to the changing global, regional, and national 
economic, social, and political landscapes. A more responsive overall institutional 
framework is required to ensure that all parties concerned at different levels act 
jointly and more vigorously to engage with and tap the expertise and resources of all 
existing and potential CAREC stakeholders. 
(iv)  More  effective  financing  coordination.  Along  with  the  changing  financial 
landscapes, CAREC needs to fine-tune its strategic positioning in the individual 
sector and the program as a whole to keep finding new ways of doing business and 
bringing new values to developing member countries to maintain CAREC as an 
effective  platform  to  increase  international  interest  in  investing  in  regional 
connectivity infrastructure. 
(v)  More  robust  sector  cooperation.  Since  its  initiation,  CAREC  priority  sector 
cooperation has achieved tangible results. Meanwhile, CAREC sector coordinating 
committees  are  facing  challenges  in  implementing  respective  sector-specific 
strategies,  formulating  more  innovative  projects,  and  mobilizing  more  financial 
resources to bridge the funding gap. 
(vi)  Greater  support  for  economic  corridor  development.  As  CAREC  countries 
become  more  physically  connected  and  continue  to  develop,  it  is  increasingly 
necessary for them to cooperate at a higher level and focus on linking markets, ideas, 
and people. Developing economic corridors can further this next generation agenda. 
Consistent efforts in this area can bring together existing and new infrastructure, 
policies, and institutions to attract private investment that will create jobs and growth. 
(vii)  Continuous  interface  with  the  private  sector.  Promoting  public–private 
partnership by actively reaching out to and engaging with the private sector has 
always been a focus of CAREC. The dual-track approach of effectively involving the 
private sector at both the program and project level will remain valuable. 
(viii)  Enhanced  regional  cooperation  through  new  membership.  Georgia  has 
expressed its interest in joining the CAREC program as its 11th member. Expanding 
CAREC’s membership will enhance the program’s regional impact and make the 
Secretariat’s coordination work more challenging. 
                                                
10 ADB.  2015.  Asian  Development  Bank  Support  for  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration.  Manila. 
http://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/evaluation-document/110946/files/adb-support-rci.pdf. 
11 CAREC’s overall institutional framework is the governing structure of the CAREC program, which defines the 
ministerial conference as the decision-making body, the senior officials’ meeting as the recommendatory body to 
the ministerial conference, and the sector coordinating committees as responsible for ensuring the effective and 
timely implementation of the medium-term priority projects and formulation of their respective strategies and action 
plans.

4   
 
5.  It is thus increasingly necessary for ADB and CAREC to demonstrate strong support, 
responsiveness,  and  flexibility  to  address  challenges  stemming  from  resource  constraints, 
effective coordination, the alignment of national and regional initiatives, and increasing technical 
demands as CAREC countries progressively move toward stronger regional cooperation.  
 
III.  THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The project impact is aligned with strengthened regional economic cooperation in the 
CAREC  region.  The  outcome  will  be  enhanced  coordination  among  CAREC  stakeholders, 
including national and sector focal points, private sector groupings, and development partners in 
the region.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The key outputs are (i) planned multisector and multitrack approach promoted by high-
level  CAREC  meetings,  (ii)  knowledge  products  for  deepening  and  widening  the  CAREC 
program prepared and disseminated, (iii) regular dialogue and information exchanged among 
ADB and other development partners, and (iv) CAREC program’s outreach and promotional 
means diversified and strengthened. 
 
8.  Planned  multisector  and  multitrack  approach  promoted  by  the  Central  Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation Program’s high-level meetings. The program will continue 
to emphasize infrastructure connectivity, but will need to complement this with other types of 
investment to support member countries’ efforts to transform their economies in step with urban 
agglomeration, economic diversification, and interventions to strengthen cooperation in other 
areas to address social and other aspects of trade expansion and improved competitiveness. 
Recognizing member countries’ different developmental levels, the program will maintain its 
multitrack  approach  in  identifying  pilot  countries,  trade  routes,  and  corridors  to  generate 
demonstrations for the rest to follow. CAREC has convened regular, significant, and high-profile 
meetings involving ministers, senior government officials, and development partners, which play 
an important role in determining the program’s direction and strategy. The TA will continue to 
support these annual meetings, as well as other side meetings and events that promote a 
multisector and multitrack approach to resolving issues associated with the implementation of 
CAREC 2020.  
 
9.  Knowledge  products  for  deepening  and  widening  the  Central  Asia  Regional 
Economic Cooperation program prepared and disseminated. Knowledge products will be 
made available in the form of publications, multimedia, and training sessions to build on and 
further develop the CAREC countries’ knowledge base. The knowledge products will address 
the CAREC countries’ particular capabilities and operational needs in the form of capacity 
building. The TA will ensure the timely production, proper dissemination, and wider reach of 
knowledge  products.  By  increasing  awareness  of  the  importance  of  regional  cooperation, 
CAREC’s contribution through its activities and projects, as well as the benefits derived from the 
program, will attract more support and develop stronger commitment and country ownership. 
 
 10.   Regular dialogue and information exchanged among ADB and other development 
partners.  The TA will continue to encourage concerted efforts from ADB, its development 
partners, and bilateral aid agencies to respond to the CAREC countries’ development needs, 
mobilize resources more effectively, and take full advantage of the benefits of this alliance.

5 
11.  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  program’s  outreach  and 
promotional means diversified and strengthened. With the support of the TA, the CAREC 
team will continue to improve and innovate in organizing outreach activities, providing several 
forums popularizing CAREC to gain broader support, and holding in-depth discussions on how 
to make CAREC more relevant and responsive. The website, which serves as the repository of 
relevant documents and publications, will be periodically maintained and improved to fulfill its 
function as the primary information portal. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $2 million equivalent, which will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from September 2016 to August 2018. ADB 
will be the executing agency. In ADB, the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division of ADB’s Central and West Asia Department will be responsible for administering and 
supervising the TA. 
 
14.  The TA will finance approximately 10 person-months of international and 360 person-
months of national consulting services, to be engaged annually during the implementation 
period.  ADB  will  employ  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). International consultants will include experts 
in sector and regional cooperation and public relations to provide technical advice and analytic 
support on a range of issues relating to regional economic cooperation and the implementation 
of CAREC strategies and action plans, as well as to help produce promotional, informational, 
and general media materials. National consultants based  at ADB headquarters and in the 
CAREC member countries will include (i) national advisors to the CAREC national focal points, 
(ii) regional cooperation coordinators, (iii) sector experts and coordinators, (iv) two regional 
cooperation program officers, (v) a regional cooperation program analyst, (vi) a web developer 
and administrator, (vii) a website and publications expert, and (viii) an administrative coordinator. 
International and national resource persons will also be engaged. The consultants’ outline terms 
of reference are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be recruited as individuals and not through 
a firm, because (i) they will be operating in different countries, (ii) their work and outputs are 
independent  of  each  other,  and  (iii)  the  CAREC  unit  within  the  Central  and  West  Asia 
Department will manage them overall. 
 
15.  The  TA  equipment  budget  includes  computers  and  small  office  equipment  to  be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to 
time). TA funds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Enhancing Coordination of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

 Key Activities with Milestones 
1.   Planned multisector and multitrack approach promoted by high-level CAREC meetings  
1.1.  CAREC ministerial conferences (at least one per year) planned and prepared by ADB’s CAREC 
  Secretariat and hosted or chaired by relevant CAREC countries (Q4 2016–Q3 2018). 
1.2.  CAREC senior officials’ meetings (at least two per year) planned and prepared by ADB’s CAREC 
  Secretariat and hosted or chaired by relevant CAREC countries (Q4 2016–Q3 2018).

8  Appendix 1 
1.3.  CAREC sector committee meetings and ABCI–JWG meetings planned and prepared by ADB’s 
  CAREC Secretariat and hosted or chaired by relevant CAREC countries (Q4 2016–Q3 2018). 
2.   Knowledge products for deepening and widening the CAREC program prepared and  
    disseminated 
2.1.  Rapid empirical studies of emerging CAREC issues undertaken by resource persons (Q4 2016–
Q4 2017). 
2.2.  New and emerging information and knowledge products disseminated through the CAREC 
website by the CWRD, workshops, and seminars as appropriate (Q4 2016–Q3 2018).  
2.3.  New and emerging information and knowledge products intended for publication and 
  dissemination reviewed (Q4 2016–Q3 2018). 
2.4.  New and emerging information and knowledge products published and disseminated as 
  appropriate (Q4 2016–Q3 2018). 
3.   Regular dialogue and information exchanged among ADB and other development partners  
3.1.  Consultation meetings and dialogue among ADB and other development partners convened 
  regularly (Q4 2016–Q3 2018).  
3.2.  Information on CAREC projects and TA projects financed and/or cofinanced by development 
partners collected annually for a consolidated CAREC investment portfolio. 
4.  CAREC program’s outreach and promotional means diversified and strengthened 
4.1.  The CAREC website refurbished, the contents updated as needed, and the database maintained 
(Q4 2016–Q2 2018). 
4.2.  Readership statistics for the CAREC website and social media gathered annually (Q4 2016–Q2 
2018). 
Inputs 
ADB: $2,000,000 (TASF-V) 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable.

assistance.

officials’ meetings, national focal points consultation meetings, sector committee meetings, and the preparation of 
the CAREC 2020 midterm review. In compliance with the joint memo from the Strategy and Policy Department and 
the Office of the General Counsel dated 29 October 2013, paragraphs 3(i) and 3(ii), use of a non-ADB member 
carrier is permitted if it is the most direct and cost-effective route. 
d  Includes costs of printing, publication, and translating documents and web pages into the Russian language. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.   A team of individual consultants will be engaged to support a range of activities under 
the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) program. Approximately 10 person-
months of international and 360 person-months of national consulting services will be engaged 
annually during the technical assistance (TA) implementation period. The indicative person-
month allocation and terms of reference are set out below. 
 
B.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Sector and Regional Cooperation Experts (8 person-months) 
 
2.  Consultant(s)  will  be  engaged  to  serve  as  experts  in  the  four  priority  sectors  of 
cooperation under CAREC. The consultant(s) will provide technical advice on a range of issues 
relating to regional economic cooperation and support the implementation of CAREC strategies 
and action plans. Preferred qualifications are a graduate degree in economics, business, or a 
related  field;  experience  undertaking  analytical  work;  and  familiarity  with  Central  Asian 
economies. The consultant will also have an understanding of the CAREC program and regional 
issues across member countries. The consultant’s responsibilities will include but not be limited 
to the following: 
(i)  analyzing regional cooperation to strengthen the overall institutional framework 
(OIF) and strategic direction of the CAREC program further; 
(ii)  performing other analytical and sector studies as required; 
(iii)  assisting in the (a) implementation and midterm review of CAREC 2020, (b) 
preparation and development of a new strategic framework, CAREC 2030, and (c) 
updating of the CAREC 2020 rolling business plan; 
(iv)  helping  to  implement  sector  strategies  and  action  plans  under  the  CAREC 
program; 
(v)  advising  the  CAREC  unit  with  regard  to  establishing  productive  working 
relationships with other regional cooperation organizations working in Central 
Asia and neighboring countries, as well as with bilateral and multilateral donors 
interested in CAREC; 
(vi)  advising on and helping to promote the participation of the private sector and 
business communities in the CAREC program; 
(vii)  helping the head of the CAREC unit to plan, prepare for, and implement CAREC 
program conferences and meetings, as well as preparing resource papers; and 
(viii)  providing other technical and coordinating support to the OIF, as required. 
 
2.  Public Relations Experts (2 person-months) 
 
3.  Public relations experts will be engaged to help produce promotional, informational, and 
general  media  materials,  in  addition  to  specific  media  packages  for  CAREC's  high-profile 
meetings, projects, and activities. Experts will also support outreach activities and arrange 
media coverage for high-profile CAREC meetings, projects, and activities, as required. The 
experts must have a bachelor's degree in communications, international relations, or a related 
field.

Appendix 3  11 
C.  National Consultants 
 
4.   The TA will strengthen support for CAREC coordination by providing a team of core 
coordinating consultants based at the Asian Development Bank (ADB) headquarters, as well as 
consultants based in the member countries. Georgia is expected to join CAREC as its 11th 
member by the end of 2016, after which national consultants will be needed in Georgia to 
support CAREC operations. 
 
5.   The consultants based in the participating countries will act as national advisors to the 
CAREC national focal points (NFPs) (see item 1 below) and regional cooperation coordinators 
(RCCs) (see item 2 below). The advisors will help the NFPs coordinate among in-country 
ministries  and  agencies  to  monitor  and  promote  the  timely  implementation  of  CAREC 
agreements  and  events.  The  advisors  and  RCCs  coordinate  with  CAREC  unit  staff  and 
consultants at ADB headquarters, and the RCCs prepare reports and organize meetings and 
other events. The advisors and RCCs ensure that national commitments made during CAREC 
events are followed up and acted upon. Since August 2012, the advisors and RCCs have been 
helping to track the progress of key CAREC activities in member countries through their monthly 
reports  to  ADB,  which  also  cover  developments  related  to  other  (non-CAREC)  regional 
cooperation initiatives. 
 
1.  National  Advisors  to  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation 
National Focal Points (11 positions, total of 264 person-months) 
 
6.   Consultants will be engaged (one per participating country) to serve as primary liaisons 
between the NFPs and ADB. The consultants must have a bachelor’s degree in economics, 
business, and/or related fields, as well as specialized experience in international organizations. 
 
7.         The consultants’ responsibilities will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  advising and otherwise assisting the NFP with regard to institutionalizing regional 
cooperation and planning and implementing regional cooperation activities; 
(ii)  assisting  in  all  aspects  of  work  related  to  the  country’s  participation  in  the 
CAREC program; 
(iii)  helping to develop and strengthen communication channels to support the NFP’s 
coordination activities related to regional cooperation and ensure the effective 
dissemination and coordination of information; 
(iv)  cooperating  closely  with  the  CAREC  unit,  the  CAREC  regional  cooperation 
coordinator, the ADB country director, and other resident mission staff to ensure 
the effective implementation of CAREC program strategies and activities; 
(v)  helping  the  government  prepare  for  CAREC  meetings  and  conferences  by 
organizing in-country consultation meetings with relevant agencies and preparing 
supporting  materials  such  as  position  papers,  briefing  notes,  speeches,  and 
presentations; 
(vi)  supporting the implementation of the strategic framework CAREC 2020 through 
CAREC sector strategies and action plans, the CAREC Institute strategy and 
action plan, and the development and maintenance of the CAREC portfolio and 
pipeline of regional projects; 
(vii)  supporting the in-country consultations for the CAREC 2020 midterm review to 
prepare and develop a next-10-year strategic framework CAREC 2030; 
(viii)  conducting monthly updates on regional cooperation activities; and 
(ix)  helping to prepare in-country studies and other research on regional cooperation 
conducted under CAREC.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
2.  Regional  Cooperation  Coordinators  (11  positions,  total  of  264  person-
months) 
 
8.   Consultants will be engaged (one per participating country) to serve as a focal point on 
regional  economic  cooperation  in  the  participating  country.  The  consultants  must  have  a 
bachelor’s degree in economics, business, or a related field, and will preferably have experience 
in regional cooperation. The consultants’ responsibilities will include but not be limited to the 
following: 
(i)  coordinating CAREC-related issues with (a) national and sector focal points in 
the government, (b) other government bodies involved in regional cooperation 
activities,  (c)  representatives  of  multilateral  institution  partners,  (d)  other 
development  partners  in  the  field,  (e)  business  communities,  and  (f)  other 
stakeholders; 
(ii)  undertaking or providing inputs into CAREC-related economic research, studies 
(sector, strategy, or thematic), and other analytical work, as well as helping to 
monitor the implementation of the strategic framework CAREC 2020, the CAREC 
2020 midterm review (with a view to preparing and developing a next 10-year 
strategic framework CAREC 2030), and other CAREC program strategies and 
activities; 
(iii)  assisting with the logistics and other arrangements for meetings and conferences 
under the OIF, including ad hoc working group meetings, sector coordinating 
committee meetings, senior officials' meetings, and ministerial conferences, as 
well as in-country workshops and outreach seminars; and 
(iv)  monitoring programs and initiatives of the government, regional organizations, 
and  other  stakeholders  on  regional  economic  cooperation,  and  identifying, 
evaluating, and recommending potential areas for collaboration. 
 
3.  Sector Experts and Coordinators (2 positions, total of 48 person-months) 
 
9.   Consultants will be engaged to undertake analysis and prepare reports as required to 
meet the requests of the CAREC senior officials' meetings and ministerial conferences. The 
consultants should have extensive knowledge of various cooperation sectors, including their 
country’s government policies and regulations. The consultants must have a university degree 
and  experience  in  development  work.  Preferred  qualifications  are  a  postgraduate  degree; 
experience in project administration, coordination, and/or regional cooperation; and technical 
knowledge of database development and management. 
 
4.  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  Core  Coordinating 
Consultants 
 
a.  Regional Cooperation Program Officer (24 person-months) 
 
10.   A consultant based at ADB headquarters will be engaged to provide technical support 
for the implementation of the CAREC OIF, which guides the CAREC program, and to the 
CAREC unit, which serves as the program’s secretariat. A graduate degree in economics, 
business, or a related field and extensive experience working in international organizations 
dealing with regional cooperation and project coordination is preferred. The consultant must 
also have a working knowledge of the CAREC program. The consultant’s responsibilities will 
include but not be limited to the following:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  preparing  periodic  monitoring  reports  on  the  implementation  of  the  CAREC 
program covering the status of proposed program activities and related initiatives, 
as well as other outstanding operational issues; 
(ii)  helping  to  prepare  CAREC-related  documents  such  as  concept  papers  and 
project profiles for regional projects, briefing notes, and other background papers; 
(iii)  providing technical and logistical assistance to the CAREC unit; 
(iv)  overseeing  logistics  and  related  arrangements  for  CAREC  ministerial 
conferences and senior officials’ meetings, preparing resource papers for these 
meetings, and performing follow-up activities; 
(v)  helping to arrange sector coordinating committee meetings, outreach seminars, 
and other CAREC workshops and meetings; and 
(vi)  creating, maintaining, and upgrading a database to analyze and measure the 
results and outcomes of the CAREC program. 
 
b.  Regional Cooperation Program Analyst (24 person-months) 
 
11.   A  consultant  based  at  ADB  headquarters  will  provide  statistical,  analytical,  and 
administrative support for the implementation of the CAREC program. The consultant must have 
a  bachelor’s  degree  in  economics,  business,  or  a  related  field,  and  will  preferably  have 
experience in regional cooperation. The consultant’s responsibilities will include but not be 
limited to the following: 
(i)  helping to update information on the regional lending and TA plans of CAREC 
multilateral institution partners; 
(ii)  providing  logistical  support  in  organizing  and  conducting  CAREC  sector 
committee meetings, senior officials’ meetings, and ministerial conferences, as 
well as outreach seminars and other workshops; 
(iii)  collecting statistical data and maintaining a database to support the requirements 
of CAREC reports and publications; 
(iv)  maintaining  an  orderly  and  up-to-date  resource  library  of  TA  files,  CAREC 
documents, consultants’ reports, and other research and background papers on 
regional cooperation (including electronic copies); and 
(v)  ensuring  the  smooth  flow  of  documents  and  communications  between  the 
CAREC unit and various divisions of the Central and West Asia Department, the 
East Asia Department, and the resident missions. 
 
c.  Web Developer and Administrator (24 person-months) 
 
12.   The consultant will primarily support the design, development, and maintenance of the 
CAREC  program  website,  with  a  focus  on  technical  issues.  The  consultant  must  have  a 
bachelor’s degree in computer science, information technology (IT), network administration, or 
another computer-related field, preferably with experience in and knowledge of database design; 
hypertext  preprocessor  or  PHP  programming;  and  structured  query  language  or  mySQL 
database, Linux Server, and Apache web server administration. The consultant’s responsibilities 
will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  helping to improve the design and navigation facility of the CAREC program 
website hosted outside of ADB, using available technologies and related free 
programs from the internet, in collaboration with the CAREC web team; 
(ii)  helping to conceptualize and execute database-related systems for the website; 
(iii)  developing, maintaining, and improving the website’s management systems for 
content, documents, projects, events, and resources; 
(iv)  helping to develop interactive maps for CAREC transport and energy corridors;

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
(v)  helping to develop, improve, and maintain the Russian-language version of the 
content management system and mirror website in Russian, in collaboration with 
the CAREC Russian language IT assistant; 
(vi)  coordinating with relevant ADB departments on IT-related matters, as necessary; 
(vii)  helping  to  administer  the  database  and  web  server  operating  systems,  as 
necessary; 
(viii)  managing the development server hosted outside ADB; and 
(ix)  undertaking other IT-related tasks necessary for updating website content. 
 
d.  Website and Publications Expert (24 person-months) 
 
13.   The consultant will help the CAREC unit develop and maintain the CAREC program 
website, and help edit and/or proof work for CAREC publications. The consultant must have a 
bachelor's degree in communications, international relations, or a related field, with extensive 
experience  in  website  development  and  maintenance.  The  consultant’s  responsibilities  will 
include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  helping to develop and maintain the CAREC program website, including the 
CAREC Institute web page content embedded in the CAREC program site; 
(ii)  developing content for all new web pages for the CAREC program website in a 
timely manner; 
(iii)  developing and implementing a schedule to ensure that all website pages are 
regularly and comprehensively updated; 
(iv)  coordinating with ADB’s Department of External Relations to develop, maintain, 
and update the CAREC program pages on the ADB website; 
(v)  providing inputs, as requested, for other CAREC informational materials; 
(vi)  editing and/or proofreading other CAREC publication materials, as requested; 
and 
(vii)  undertaking other related activities assigned by the CAREC unit, such as the 
preparation of presentation materials, reports, and other documents to be used in 
high-level meetings and conferences. 
 
e.  Administrative Coordinators (2 positions, 48 person-months) 
 
14.   Administrative coordinators will be engaged to provide administrative support for all 
aspects of the CAREC unit’s work. The coordinators must have a bachelor's degree in a related 
field, preferably with experience in administrative support and cooperation work. 
 
D.  Other Consultants 
 
1.  International and National Resource Persons 
 
15.   Resource  persons  may  be  engaged  to  work  closely  with  responsible  ADB  staff  in 
preparing specific materials and delivering presentations at meetings and workshops.
author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation  
  IT  –  information technology 
NFP  –  national focal point 
OIF  –  overall institutional framework 
RCC  –  regional cooperation coordinator 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  W. Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  S. O’Sullivan, Central and West Asia Department 
Director  P. Srivastava, Officer-in-Charge, Regional Cooperation and Operations 
Coordination Division (CWRC) 
   
Team leader  G. Wu, Regional Cooperation Specialist, CWRC 
Team members  W. Hong, Principal Regional Cooperation Specialist, CWRC  
K. Rosbach, Economist (Regional Cooperation), CWRC  
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
